channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: 11 Takeaways From The Times’s Investigation Into Trump’s Wealth
item.media:description: President Trump received today’s equivalent of over $400 million from the real estate empire of his father, Fred C. Trump, whose photograph sits behind him in the Oval Office.
item.description: Based on a trove of confidential financial records, the Times report offers the first comprehensive look at the inherited fortune and tax dodges that guaranteed Donald Trump a gilded life.
item.dc:creator: RUSS BUETTNER, SUSANNE CRAIG and DAVID BARSTOW

item.title: Trump Taunts Christine Blasey Ford at Rally
item.description: At a campaign event in Mississippi, the president went further than ever before in directly assailing Dr. Blasey, who has accused Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh of sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN and PETER BAKER

item.title: F.B.I. to End Kavanaugh Inquiry as Soon as Wednesday, With Vote Coming This Week
item.media:description: The F.B.I.’s investigation into sexual assault and sexual misconduct allegations against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh appears to be moving quickly.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: Senator Mitch McConnell’s promise to wrap up Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s confirmation gave it an air of inevitability, but five undecided senators are refusing to tip their hands.
item.dc:creator: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Kavanaugh’s 1983 Letter Offers Inside Look at High School Clique
item.media:description: Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh testifying last week before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
item.description: Brett Kavanaugh was a member of a hard-partying group of football players, and his behavior was more raucous than he has publicly described.
item.dc:creator: KATE KELLY and DAVID ENRICH

item.title: Where Indonesia Quake Turned Ground to Jelly, People and Homes Are Unaccounted For
item.media:description: A destroyed neighborhood in Palu, Indonesia. Hundreds of buildings were destroyed by liquefaction, which causes soil to lose its ability to support structures.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: In one part of Palu, hundreds of buildings flowed sideways before being buried. Only now has heavy equipment been brought in to the search for the missing.
item.dc:creator: FIRA ABDURACHMAN, ADAM DEAN and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Facebook Hack Puts Thousands of Other Sites at Risk
item.media:description: Ten years ago, Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg introduced a tool that connects other sites and apps to Facebook passwords. That convenience came with a risk.
item.description: Ten years ago, the social network introduced a password system that connected it to a broad swath of the internet. Now we are seeing the downside.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC and KATE CONGER

item.title: State of the Art: Why You Shouldn’t Use Facebook to Log In to Other Sites
item.media:description: Facebook said Tuesday that it had “no evidence” that attackers got into other sites through a hack of its login feature.
item.description: Facebook offered a convenient and secure way to sign up for online services. A major hack shows it failed at its one job.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: ‘Better to Drown’: A Greek Refugee Camp’s Epidemic of Misery
item.media:description: Refugees from Afghanistan at a makeshift camp outside Moria, in Lesbos, Greece. Moria has become the most visible symbol of the hard-line stance European countries have taken on migrants since 2016.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Trauma, psychosis and suicide attempts have become common occurrences at Moria, a Greek island camp, where aid groups warn of a mental health crisis.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Homeland Security’s Computers Couldn’t Track Separated Families, Report Finds
item.media:description: Migrant children at a tent encampment in Tornillo, Tex., in June. Some parents didn’t understand that they would be separated from their children at the border, a report found.
item.description: The U.S. agency was so unprepared for the Trump administration’s zero-tolerance immigration policy that it was unable to keep track of those separated at the border.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON
item.category: Homeland Security Office of Inspector General

item.title: Fred Trump, M.L.B., Lady Gaga: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: Donald Trump and his father, Fred Trump, in the 1980s. The son benefited from his father’s vast real estate empire.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: JILLIAN RAYFIELD

item.title: New York Today: New York Today: Catcalling on Sidewalks
item.media:description: “Boys will be boys.”
item.description: Wednesday: A spike in reports of street harassment around the city, and today’s test presidential alert.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA S. LEVINE

item.title: California Today: California Today: What is Wrong With the Salesforce Transit Center
item.media:description: The Salesforce Transit Center in February, six months before it opened.
item.description: Wednesday: The terminal’s cracked beams, Californians are accused of inciting violence in Charlottesville, and how Joe Ide’s L.A. youth shapes his fiction.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER and INYOUNG KANG

item.title: Donald Trump and the Self-Made Sham
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Now let’s see your tax returns, Mr. President.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: A Bad Move That Could End Up Exposing Kids to Chemicals
item.description: Without explaining why, the E.P.A. has sidelined its top children’s health advocate.
item.dc:creator: PHILIP J. LANDRIGAN and LYNN R. GOLDMAN

item.title: The Meritocracy Against Itself
item.media:description: Yale Law School students protesting on Capitol Hill last week.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: How Ivy League resentments took over the Kavanaugh debate.
item.dc:creator: ROSS DOUTHAT

item.title: Russian Meddling Is a Symptom, Not the Disease
item.media:description: Facebook pages created by a Russian troll factory, the Internet Research Agency, on display at a House Intelligence Committee hearing last November.
item.description: More worrisome than foreign interference in our elections is how our own tech and media companies feed and profit from our deepening domestic political polarization.
item.dc:creator: ZEYNEP TUFEKCI
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: The American Civil War, Part II
item.media:description: Protesters in a hallway tried to disrupt a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing last week.
item.description: The nation is deeply divided, with each side seeing the other as “the enemy.”
item.dc:creator: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

item.title: The Right-Wing Rot at the Heart of the German State
item.media:description: Police officers with a protester seeking to block coal mining in the Hambach Forest near Cologne, Germany.
item.description: Recent events make clear that extremists have allies deep inside the government.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS MEANEY and SASKIA SCHÄFER

item.title: Am I a Lawn Mower Parent?
item.description: We need to let kids learn to be tough. But we also need to show them love.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER FINNEY BOYLAN

item.title: Sorry, President Trump, Decency Beats Dollars
item.media:description: A protester last week on Capitol Hill.
item.description: A blue wave in the midterms would be a validation of the best American values.
item.dc:creator: FRANK BRUNI

item.title: The Stone: Misogyny Rules: A War of Two Worlds
item.media:description: A majority of the senators were male at the executive session last week on moving Brett Kavanaugh's nomination out of the Judiciary Committee.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: The battle over the Kavanaugh hearings is not about truth. It is about meaning.
item.dc:creator: BONNIE MANN

item.title: Amazon’s Surrender Is Inspiring
item.media:description: A worker prepares a package at an Amazon fulfillment center in Baltimore. Amazon announced Tuesday that it would raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour for its United States employees.
item.description: How the country might return to a time when corporate executives rejected pure greed.
item.dc:creator: DAVID LEONHARDT

item.title: Loose Ends: The United Texts of America
item.media:credit: Illustration by Jeffrey Henson Scales, photographs by Chad Batka for The New York Times and d3sign/Moment, via Getty Images
item.description: We’ll be hearing from the president. Here’s how that might go.
item.dc:creator: KATE GREATHEAD and TEDDY WAYNE

item.title: Welcome to Right Field. Beware the Yankee Fans.
item.media:description: As Mookie Betts of the Red Sox and fans watched a home run sail into the right-field bleachers in August 2017, one spectator took the opportunity to chat with Betts.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: Visiting right fielders often get an earful from fans at Yankee Stadium. In October, it only gets worse.
item.dc:creator: BILLY WITZ

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: What a Book Critic Finds in Mark Judge’s ‘Wasted’ 21 Years Later
item.description: Mark Judge’s 1997 memoir, “Wasted,” captures both the milieu in which the author and Brett Kavanaugh were raised, and prevailing ideas of masculinity in the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: DWIGHT GARNER
item.category: Wasted: Tales of a GenX Drunk (Book)

item.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry Is Awarded to 3 Scientists for Using Evolution in Design of Molecules
item.media:description: The 2018 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Frances H. Arnold, George P. Smith and Gregory P. Winter for their work in evolutionary science.
item.description: Frances H. Arnold of the U.S. received half the prize, while her compatriot George P. Smith and Gregory P. Winter of Britain shared the other half.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: International Court Orders U.S. to Ease Some Iran Sanctions
item.media:description: Iran is trying to nullify the new round of sanctions, which have inflicted pain on its troubled economy.
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.description: The International Court of Justice said in a nonbinding ruling that Washington should lessen restrictions that affect humanitarian aid and civilian aviation safety.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Iraq Names New President and Prime Minister, Ending Deadlock
item.media:description: Barham Salih, right, the newly elected president of Iraq, and Adel Abdul Mahdi, left, the newly named prime minister, in Baghdad on Tuesday.
item.description: The Iraqi Parliament elected as president the Kurdish politician Barham Salih, who immediately named Adel Abdul Mahdi, a Shiite, prime minister-designate, ending months of deadlock.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Chicago Police Officer Defends His Shooting of Laquan McDonald
item.media:description: Jason Van Dyke, a Chicago police officer, testified during his murder trial for the shooting death of Laquan McDonald, 17.
item.description: Officer Jason Van Dyke, on trial for first-degree murder, took the stand and said the teenager waved a knife at him. A police video did not show that.
item.dc:creator: MITCH SMITH

item.title: ‘Take Out’ Russian Missiles? U.S. Envoy’s Remark Spurs Anger, and Pullback
item.media:description: Kay Bailey Hutchison, the American ambassador to NATO, said she had not meant to suggest an American pre-emptive strike against Russian missiles.
item.description: The American ambassador to NATO used vague language that sounded like an American threat to strike Russian missiles preemptively. She later clarified her meaning.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Missing in the G.O.P.: Black and Hispanic Nominees for Governor
item.media:description: Nikki Haley and Bobby Jindal, both Indian-Americans and former Republican governors, were once among several minority politicians in the G.O.P. who led states.
item.description: There are 36 governor races this year. In about 30 of them, the Republican nominees are white men.
item.dc:creator: ASTEAD W. HERNDON

item.title: Marks & Spencer Is Struggling. Can Knickers, Candy and Colin the Caterpillar Cakes Save It?
item.media:description: The Marks & Spencer store in Stockton-on-Tees, England, was one of oldest branches of the British retailer. It closed in August.
item.media:credit: Benjamin Quinton for The New York Times
item.description: The British icon has played a crucial role in the daily lives of millions for more than 100 years, but financial problems and store closings have made its future uncertain.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH PATON

item.title: THIS IS A TEST: Cellphones Across the U.S. Will Get a ‘Presidential Alert’
item.media:description: Cellphones across the United States — and some other wireless devices, like the Apple Watch — will get the debut test message from the Wireless Emergency Alert System on Wednesday. There is no way to opt out.
item.description: The alert, at 2:18 p.m. Wednesday, will be the first nationwide test of a wireless emergency alert system, designed to warn of a major threat, like a terror attack or natural disaster.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: Travel Tips: Should You Tip Your Uber Driver? If So, How Much?
item.description: Uber added tipping to its app just over a year ago, and other rideshare services have allowed riders to tip their drivers for longer than that. But do drivers expect you to tip? Do they rely on them?
item.dc:creator: KRISTIN WONG

item.title: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Help You Start Packing Your Lunch
item.media:description: A lunchbox with muffins and an apple.
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times
item.description: Goodbye, #saddesklunch.
item.dc:creator: MARISA MCCLELLAN

item.title: 8 Questions About Social Security Answered as Election Day Nears
item.description: Every two years, voters — whether they already count on the program, expect to or question paying into it — try to make sense of competing claims about it. It’s that time again.
item.dc:creator: TARA SIEGEL BERNARD and KARL RUSSELL

item.title: Everyone Should Have a Postpartum Doula
item.media:description: Meema Spadola, right, a postpartum doula in New York, helps a pair of new parents in Brooklyn bathe their newborn.
item.media:credit: Andre D. Wagner for The New York Times
item.description: Because when a baby comes, friends and families don’t always know how to help.
item.dc:creator: ZOE GREENBERG

item.title: Fan Bingbing, China’s Most Famous Actress, Faces Huge Fines in Tax Evasion
item.media:description: Fan Bingbing at the Cannes Film Festival in France in May.
item.description: Ms. Fan, who has disappeared from public view for months, vastly underreported her income, the Chinese state news media said.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: When It Comes to Dinner, Less Is More
item.media:description: The best thing to do with a whole roast chicken? Carve it and pair it with some vinegared potatoes to catch all those juices and drippings.
item.media:credit: Michael Graydon & Nikole Herriott for The New York Times. Prop Stylist: Kalen Kaminski.
item.description: You don’t need everything at the market to make a meal interesting. Alison Roman lays out her supper strategy.
item.dc:creator: ALISON ROMAN

item.title: Best of Late Night: Stephen Colbert Calls Trump ‘an Extraordinarily Wealthy Toddler’
item.media:description: Stephen Colbert said: “So, let me get this straight: At one point, Donald Trump was an extraordinarily wealthy toddler. And today? He is still that.”
item.description: Mr. Colbert referred to a New York Times report showing that President Trump received large cash gifts as a toddler. Little has changed, Mr. Colbert said.
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: David Hockney Wouldn’t Paint the Queen. But He Made Her a Stained-Glass Window.
item.media:description: David Hockney in his London living room in September. On his right is a facsimile of the of a stained- glass window he designed, which was formally dedicated at Westminster Abbey on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Suzanne Plunkett for The New York Times
item.description: The British painter says he is not a churchgoer, but on Tuesday a window that he designed was formally dedicated in Westminster Abbey.
item.dc:creator: FARAH NAYERI
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: In Australia, Cervical Cancer Could Soon Be Eliminated
item.media:description: Professor Ian Frazer, a co-creator of the HPV vaccine, Gardasil, said he hoped other countries would follow Australia’s lead.
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.description: The government started a program to distribute the HPV vaccine for free to girls more than a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: LIVIA ALBECK-RIPKA

item.title: Strategies: The New iPhones Look Fine. But My Old One Is Better Than Ever.
item.description: With a fresh battery and operating system, an aging iPhone 6 seems faster than ever. Why would Apple take steps to discourage a new purchase?
item.dc:creator: JEFF SOMMER

item.title: Trilobites: The Marvelous Filters in the Manta Ray’s Mouth
item.media:description: Manta rays' filtration system causes particles to glide over its straining system, rather than going through, preventing clogging.
item.description: The car-sized, kite-shaped fishes don’t have to clear their throats because of their unique method of filtration that could be applied to preventing plastic pollution in the seas.
item.dc:creator: VERONIQUE GREENWOOD

item.title: The Confidence Gap for Girls: 5 Tips for Parents of Tween and Teen Girls
item.description: Between the ages of 8 and 14, girls’ confidence levels fall by 30 percent. Fighting it requires taking some risks.
item.dc:creator: CLAIRE SHIPMAN, KATTY KAY and JILLELLYN RILEY
